content:
Use these settings: incoming IMAP outlook.office365.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address; outgoing smtp.office365.com, 587, STARTTLS, OAuth2, email address. Same for POP, except incoming port 995.

Using any other server names will not offer OAuth2 as authentication, which will be mandatory after mid Sept.

content:
One thing that's different with outlook (and gmail) accounts is that they automatically copy sent messages to Sent, so 'Place a copy in' in Account Settings, Copies & Folders must be unchecked. From the add-on support page:

"With Microsoft accounts sent mails are also automatically put into the 'Sent' folder. It is not possible to send an email without this happening. This is even true if 'No copy' is used. In the settings of this add-on, the option "additional copy to the 'Sent' folder" for Microsoft accounts is therefore automatically activated and cannot be deactivated."

You might be able achieve your goal with filters acting on the Sent folder, but they would have to be run manually, as filters only run automatically on the Inbox.
creator: sfhowes

creator: sfhowes

content:
sfhowes said
I haven't tried it, but using POP instead of IMAP for outlook accounts might avoid the automatic copying to Sent.

Thanks for yet another idea. I tried using filters, but that didn't work unfortunately for the reason you gave. I also think IMAP is preferred over POP generally speaking if I'm not mistaken, so by switching to POP I might be losing some features/advantages that come with IMAP?
creator: thunderbirds_are_go

content: The main advantage of IMAP over POP is that mail is stored on the server, so it can be synced over multiple devices with the account. Plus, IMAP can sync all the folders, while POP downloads just the Inbox. But if those features are as important to you than the ability to store sent messages in the receiving folder, it's worth setting up a POP account for testing purposes.
creator: sfhowes

content:
sfhowes said
The main advantage of IMAP over POP is that mail is stored on the server, so it can be synced over multiple devices with the account. Plus, IMAP can sync all the folders, while POP downloads just the Inbox. But if those features are as important to you than the ability to store sent messages in the receiving folder, it's worth setting up a POP account for testing purposes.

Thanks for clarifying further. Given those advantages, I'd prefer to stick with IMAP, and will have to accept that I therefore can't achieve what I've asked in this question. Thanks again for the ideas.
creator: thunderbirds_are_go

content:
The decision to automatically make a copy of sent mail in the sent folder for each mail traversing their SMTP servers is one made by Microsoft. I feel that I also have to make this distinction clear, it is mail sent via their SMTP server and is totally independent of the incoming mail protocol used.

For years now I have been suggesting to folk that they disable Thunderbird's copy in account settings as they really do not need two copies of every mail they send and Microsoft do not allow an "opt out" of their copy. I do not see that happening anytime soon either.

Thunderbird can natively place a copy of a reply in the folder the replied message resides, if it is a reply. I have that as my default for some accounts in local folders. Just put a tick in the relevant box in settings.

It is also worth noting that placing a check in the BCC and CC addresses without entering any address will cause them to show in the compose window by default, rather than be hidden behind button.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Hello there

This situation can be configured with thunderbird to leave your inbox to make a copy to rename your inbox to erase the inbox .msf file.

Please read the following text . Inbox emails stays blank. Or emails become blank after using the email program.

Exit Thunderbird. Make several copies of the file "Inbox" in safe places (outside your profile folder). Rename the file "Inbox" to "InboxOld". Delete the file "Inbox.msf". Start Thunderbird. It will create a new, empty Inbox.

There should be a new folder InboxOld visible in the folder pane. Right-click it and select "Compact This Folder". If this succeeds, try to open it.

If you can open it without problems, you are done and you can delete the copies (after you make very sure).

Greetings Firefox volunteer.

content:
First, if it was an IMAP account, nothing is lost. Just recreate it. If it was a POP account, it depends on how you removed it. During the removal, the first pane shown after clicking to remove includes a checkbox to remove data. If you left that unticked, then your messages should all still be in the profile. You can verify that by these steps: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down left side to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - you are now in the profile, click the Mail folder and I believe it will show your removed account name. - click that and I believe you will see you message folders, such as input, input.msf, sent, sent.msf, etc.

Report back on that and we can discuss next steps
creator: davidsk

content: You're referring to a backup copy of the profile? The msf files are useless, as they are just indexes, which thunderbird will rebuild. content:
Paul said
Thanks, but I don't use IMAP.

Just accept you can not rename those folders. It may be that they are defined for specific functions, but you can not rename them without breaking something else so the option is not offered. Many of the default folders are included in the localization of Thunderbird into languages other than English which may impact on the ability to rename.

Fundamentally you will have an inbox and a trash etc, because Thunderbird is programed that way.

If you have ideas or suggestions, I suggest you use the link on the help menu in Thunderbird and offer them in the correct place. That menu entry links to here https://connect.mozilla.org/

content: Thunderbird is only a messenger. If you receive a message of incorrect password, that means that the server setup you provided, and the email address and password you provided, are not being accepted by the email host. Sometimes this happens because the email host (such as Gmail) requires a different password when accessed from an PC email client.

creator: ivanwarner247

content:
Unfortunately most of the inability to connect issues that arrive post an update fall to defective antivirus or other security software. So if you are immediately post update the following may see things start working and if they do, will provide a clue as the the source.

The first eliminates addons in Thunderbird primarily, but also antivirus toolbars. Both can be prone to issues post update. The second removes any number of startup programs from the operating system. Including any third party antivirus/ software firewall which may see the system begin to function correctly and sign you in.


  • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
  • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

Note operating system safe mode requires a wired internet connection. WiFi is not available in safe mode.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: play2

content:
Uninstall/reinstall seldom fixes issues in the separate profile folder. But it can't do any harm.

You could try rebuilding the Inbox by following these instructions:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Compacting_folders#Real_fix

basically, you copy the existing messages to another folder, then close TB and delete the mbox and .msf files for Inbox. When TB restarts, a new Inbox is automatically created and synced with the IMAP folder.
creator: sfhowes

content:
This is definitely a bug with the new Nebula T-bird Version 128, and possibly inter-related to the user's Window version 10 or 11. (See below)

Note about this problem: These problem emails that were being re-named by T-bird/Nebula, were all generated from same source, a Google Workspace email app in my website. Thunderbird changed them all to read the same in both the "From" and "Correspondent" field. This was a problem because I routinely need to refer to them by name, and they're moved to an applicable folder for that reason. No other email was re-named. All email in that folder from the same source was.

Fixing it: When I uninstalled and re-installed the same T-bird version, it didn't fix it the problem. When I uninstalled again, and then re-installed the prior version, 115.13 Supernova, the emails are named correctly. Now it's set to not update.

The strange thing about the original problem is that T-bird is grabbing the source email from the Microsoft Exchange server and changing them. All the above effected T-bird email always displayed correctly in Outlook mail.

May be related to Windows version??? This problem was on my HP AIO desktop running Windows 10. Meanwhile, my HP laptop running Windows 11 also updated T-bird before I could stop it. However, it kept the same emails named correctly, but it added the sender's email in both the "From" and "Correspondents" fields in all emails. Not just the prior miss-named ones. Despite it taking up line space and being redundant, I could have lived with this on the AIO.
creator: play2

content:
When you downgraded from 128 to 115, did you start with a new profile and add the account? If you did, and the names were correct, that is because a new Inbox was created - the same result as the Real fix mentioned above.

In TB 128, the message list display format can be set in Settings/General/Reading & Display.
creator: sfhowes
